Graphical abstract The first heterogeneous carbonylation reaction carried out with palladium catalysts immobilised on phosphonium ion modified silica supports is reported. The supported ionic liquid phases were characterised by solid state NMR and FT-IR measurements. The presence of the phosphonium ions on the surface made it possible to carry out double carbonylation in apolar toluene efficiently that resulted in reduced metal leaching. The introduction of dicationic moieties on the solid support has been proved to lead to a further increase in catalyst stability. The catalysts were proved to produce α-ketoamide products with excellent selectivity in the carbonylation of iodoarenes with aliphatic amines while monocarbonylation was the only reaction observed with aniline derivatives. The catalysts could be recycled and used in at least 10 subsequent runs under optimised conditions. Keywords Carbonylation Heterogeneous catalysis Immobilisation Palladium Supported catalysts 1 Introduction Palladium-catalysed double carbonylation of aryl halides, first reported by Yamamoto in 1982 [1], has become one of the most widespread methods for the synthesis of α-ketoamides [2,3]. The oxoamide functionality is an important motif in a great variety of natural and non-natural biologically active compounds [2]. α-Ketoamides can be used as starting material in Mannich-type reactions [2] and in a number of transformations leading to heterocycles [4] or 13C-labeled phenethylamines [5]. The process, that involves the reaction of aryl halides with amines using carbon monoxide as CO source, leads to α-ketoamides via double CO insertion and carboxamides via a competing monocarbonylation [6]. The selectivity of the reaction is affected by a number of parameters such as temperature, CO pressure, the choice of solvent and added base, as well as by the structure of the reaction partners. Fortunately, the reaction can be made selective in most cases by applying appropriate conditions. However, it suffers from the common drawbacks of homogeneous catalytic reactions such as the problem of catalyst recovery and recycling as well as metal-contamination of the crude products. A great variety of methodologies have been developed to circumvent these drawbacks such as the use of polymeric or dendritic ligands, self-supported catalysts, biphasic catalysis or application of ionic liquids as solvents [7] Heterogeneous catalysts, prepared by anchoring metal complexes on solid materials or depositing metal nanoparticles on surfaces modified with stabilising organic moieties, may ensure an easy separation of products as well as an efficient catalyst recycling. As another advantage, they are also suitable for continuous flow applications. Several useful supported palladium catalysts were developed for CC coupling [8] as well as for other Pd-catalysed reactions [9]. The efficiency of carbonylation could also be enhanced by the use of heterogeneous palladium catalysts to facilitate catalyst separation and recycling [10]. A great variety of supported catalysts have been used successfully in monocarbonylation. Some recent examples include the application of a palladium catalyst immobilised by a polymer anchored Schiff base ligand [11], a palladium-1,10-phenanthroline complex encaged in Y zeolite [12] or palladium nanoparticles dispersed on siliceous mesocellular foam [13]. Double carbonylation reactions catalysed by heterogeneous palladium catalysts are still rare. A silica-supported polytitazane–palladium (Ti–N–Pd) compound [14], a Pd/C+PPh3 catalyst system [15] and palladium-phosphine complexes grafted onto mesoporous silica (SBA-15) (SBA=Santa Barbara Amorphous, mesoporous silica) [16] were proved to be suitable catalysts. In recent studies, heterogeneous double carbonylation was mainly carried out in the presence of palladium nanoparticles that were supported on a cross-linked functional polymer [17], on a triazine framework [18] or on a mesoporous poly-melamine-formaldehyde material [19]. In some cases insufficient selectivity for the α-ketoamide product [17] or a loss of activity of the recycled catalyst [18] was observed. Even the catalysts with highest efficiency [16,19] were tested only up to 6 cycles. Catalytically active palladium species may be stabilised efficiently with the help of ionic liquids [20]. Accordingly, imidazolium ionic liquids (ILs) immobilised on silica were found to be suitable supports for palladium catalysts used in aminocarbonylation [21–24] and double carbonylation [25,26]. In the latter reactions the application of polar solvents was necessary to achieve good selectivity and efficient recyclability. At the same time a low but not satisfactory metal leaching was detected under these conditions. Investigation of aminocarbonylation reactions carried out in ILs as solvents [27] showed that catalytic activity of palladium nanoparticles in phosphonium-type ILs surpasses the results obtained in imidazolium salts [28]. This proves a better stabilisation effect of the former ILs that might be preserved even after immobilisation on a solid surface. The introduction of multiple ionic liquid-like functionalities into polymeric supports was also found to enhance catalyst stability in other palladium-catalysed reactions such as Heck coupling [29]. Based on these findings we undertook to explore the applicability of palladium catalysts immobilised on supported ionic liquid phases (SILPs) with phosphonium cations in double carbonylation of aryl iodides. The possibility of supporting a dicationic IL on silica, in order to improve the stability of the catalysts, was also taken into account. To the best of our knowledge this is the first example for the use of SILPs with phosphonium ions as supports for catalysts in double carbonylation/aminocarbonylation reactions. 2 Experimental Reaction mixtures were analysed by gas chromatography (Hewlett Packard 5890) and GC–MS (Hewlett Packard 5971A GC–MSD, HP-1 column). Conversions and selectivities of the reactions were determined by GC. The palladium-content of the catalysts and palladium leaching were determined by ICP-AES (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy). Solid phase NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the products were obtained in CDCl3 or DMSO-d 6 (as indicated in 2.4. Characterisation of the products) at 500.15MHz and 125.78MHz, respectively, using a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer. NMR spectra of isolated products correspond well to those reported previously [16,21,26,30–33]. Minor components were characterised using GC–MS. FT-IR spectra were measured on a BRUKER Vertex 70 type spectrometer with a Bruker Platinum ATR (attenuated total reflection) adapter without sample preparation. The spectra were recorded at a resolution of 2cm−1 with a room temperature DTGS (deuterated triglycine sulfate) detector (512 scans were co-added). Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a Netzsch Thermische Analyse TG209 Cell instrument (heating rate 5°C/min). Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) investigations were carried out by a JEOL 3010 high resolution TEM operating at 300kV, with a point resolution of 0.17nm. The microscope was equipped with a GATAN Tridiem energy filter used for electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) elemental mapping. The samples were suspended in ethanol and drop-dried on carbon-coated microgrids for the measurements of the microstructure of the catalyst particles and their distribution over the support. The surface composition of CAT-2 was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) performed by a KRATOS XSAM 800 XPS machine. Al Kα characteristic X-ray line, 40eV pass energy and FAT mode were applied for recording the XPS lines of Pd 3d, C 1s, O 1s, Br 3d, F 1s, N 1s, P 2p and Si 2p. C 1s binding energy at 284.8eV was used as reference for charge compensation. The surface concentrations of the elements were calculated from the integral intensities of the XPS lines using sensitivity factors given by the manufacturer. 2.1 Preparation of supports 2.1.1 Preparation of SILP-1 A mixture of 3-chloropropyl-triethoxysilane (1ml, 4.16mmol), triphenylphosphine (1.09g, 4.16mmol), potassium iodide (1.09g, 6.57mmol), tetrabutylammonium iodide (0.32g, 0.87mmol) and acetonitrile (10ml) was refluxed under argon at 90°C for 24h. The precipitated salt was removed by filtration from the hot solution under inert conditions. Acetonitrile was evaporated and the solid residue was washed with 3×2ml acetonitrile and dried in vacuo at 60°C for 8h to obtain 2.29g of ((3-triethoxysilyl)propyl)triphenylphosphonium iodide (1) (Yield: 93%). 1H and 13C NMR of 1 corresponded well to the data of the analogous bromide salt [34]. 1H NMR(DMSO-d 6) δ: 7.64–7.92 (m, 15H); 3.67 (q, J =7.0Hz, 6H); 3.52–3.62 (m, 2H); 1.53–1.65 (m, 2H); 1.05 (t, J =7.0Hz, 9H); 0.95 (t, J =7.0Hz, 2H). 13C NMR(DMSO-d 6) δ: 134.8 (d, J =3.0Hz); 133.3 (d, J =10.0Hz); 130.1 (d, J =12.3Hz); 118.3 (d, J =85.4Hz); 57.7; 22.8 (d, J =47.9Hz); 18.0; 16.2 (d, J =3.8Hz); 11.2. A mixture of 1 (500mg, 0.84mmol), 6ml toluene and 1g silica (Kieselgel 60 (0.040–0.063mm), Merck, pre-treated by heating for 8h at 220°C) was heated under argon at 120°C for 24h. Then the solid material was filtered, washed with 2ml toluene, 2ml methanol and 2ml diethyl ether and dried in vacuo at 60°C for 8h. Organic content: 0.55mmol/g modified silica (determined from the weight increase after heating the material to constant weight at 150°C in vacuo). 1g of 2 was placed to a round bottomed flask, suspended in 4ml methanol and stirred. Glyoxal (318μl, 40% solution in water, 2.8mmol) was added dropwise and the mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature. The color of the reaction mixture changed to light brown. Then 295.7mg ammonium chloride (5.6mmol) and 439μl formaldehyde (35% solution in water, 5.6mmol) were added and the mixture was diluted with 1ml methanol. After a one hour-long reflux, 1μl phosphoric acid (85%, 0.012mmol) was added and the mixture was refluxed for 12h. The hot reaction mixture was filtered under inert conditions and was washed with 30ml methanol and 5ml diethyl ether and then dried in vacuo at 60°C for 8h to obtain 1.028g of 3. A mixture of the modified silica gel 3 (1.0g), 2.26g of (3-bromopropyl) triphenylphosphonium bromide (4) (4.87mmol), prepared by a known method [35] and 10ml toluene were refluxed under argon for 24h. The solid material was filtered under inert conditions and washed with 3×5ml toluene and 3×5ml diethyl ether and then dried in vacuo at 60°C for 8h to obtain 1.08g of supported ionic liquid phase SILP-2. Based on the weight increase and thermogravimetric analysis of SILP-2 (organic content: 16.5%) 32% of the surface imidazole moieties were alkylated. This corresponds to 0.16mmol dicationic moieties/g modified silica. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of CAT-0 200mg [MePh3P][Br] and 0.02mmol (20.7mg) Pd2(dba)3·CHCl3 (dba=dibenzylideneacetone) was dissolved in 5ml acetonitrile. The mixture was stirred for 15min at room temperature. Then 550mg silica (Kieselgel 60 (0.040–0.063mm), Merck, pre-treated by heating for 5h at 250°C) was added under stirring and the resulting mixture was stirred for 24h. The solvents were removed in vacuo and the catalyst was dried at 40°C in vacuo for 3h and was stored under argon until use. Palladium content of the catalyst: 0.54% (determined by ICP-AES). 2.2.2 Preparation of CAT-1 and CAT-2 A solution of 120mg Pd2(dba)3·CHCl3 (0.115mmol) in 4ml THF and 4ml acetonitrile was stirred for 15min under inert conditions at room temperature. Then 1g modified silica gel (SILP-1 or SILP-2) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 24h at room temperature. The solvents were evaporated and the catalyst was dried in vacuo at 50 °C for 6h. Palladium content of the catalysts: 0.75% (CAT-1) and 1.95% (CAT-2) (determined by ICP-AES). 2.2.3 Preparation of CAT-3 A solution of 20.7mg Pd2(dba)3·CHCl3 (0.115mmol) in 4ml THF and 4ml acetonitrile was stirred for 15min under inert conditions at room temperature. Then 550mg modified silica gel (SILP-2) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 24h at room temperature. The solid material was filtered and dried in vacuo at 50 °C for 6h. Palladium content of the catalyst: 0.74% (determined by ICP-AES). 2.3 General procedures for catalytic reactions 2.3.1 Catalytic reactions at atmospheric pressure In a typical experiment a solution containing the palladium catalyst (with 2.8μmol Pd-content) was placed in a Schlenk-tube. Under argon, 0.2mmol (22.5μl) iodobenzene (7a), 0.5mmol (44μl) morpholine (8a), 0.25mmol (35μl) triethylamine and 1ml DMF was added and the atmosphere was changed to carbon monoxide. The reaction was conducted for 3 or 8h at 100°C. The catalyst was removed by filtration and the reaction mixture was analysed by GC and GC–MS. 2.3.2 Catalytic reactions at elevated pressure In a typical experiment the catalyst (containing 2.8μmol Pd) was placed in a stainless steel autoclave. The aryl iodide (0.2mmol), amine (0.5mmol), base (35μl, 0.25mmol) and solvent (1ml) were transferred into it under an inert atmosphere. It was charged with carbon monoxide (30bar) and heated with stirring in an oil bath at 100°C. After cooling to room temperature the catalyst was removed by filtration and was reused without further purification. The reaction mixture was analysed by gas chromatography. The phosphonium salt with 3-triethoxypropyl functionality (1) that enables condensation with surface OH groups of silica, could be synthesized only after an ion exchange of the starting 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane (Scheme 1 ). Functionalisation of the silica support with phosphonium salt 1 was followed by solid phase NMR measurements. In the 13C CP MAS (cross polarisation magic angle spinning) NMR spectrum of SILP-1 (Fig. S1), signals of the carbon atoms of the propyl group (14.4ppm, 16.8ppm and 24.7ppm) as well as those assigned to the carbon atoms of the aromatic ring (in the region of 118.7–134.2ppm) could be distinguished. The lack of peaks of ethoxy groups proved the successful grafting of the ionic liquid on the surface. In the 29Si CP MAS NMR spectrum, the three peaks situated at −67.7 and −58.6ppm were assigned to T3 (Si(OSi)3R) and T2 (Si(OSi)2ROH) organosiloxane moieties (Fig. S2) which supported the formation of covalent bonds between the phosphonium cation and silica through a propylene spacer [37]. The signal at 18.0ppm in the 31P CP MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. S3) corresponded well to the phosphorous atom of a phosphonium salt. A silica support with a dicationic side chain (SILP-2) was prepared by a stepwise procedure depicted in Scheme 2 . The imidazole-functionalised silica (3) was obtained in the reaction of 3-aminopropyl-silica (2) with glyoxal, formaldehyde and ammonium chloride according to the method of Bayero [38]. Then the imidazole ring was alkylated with phosphonium salt 4 to construct the dicationic moiety [35]. Solid phase NMR measurements and infrared spectroscopy were used to follow the modification steps. In the FT-IR spectrum of 2 the appearance of NH stretching (3292 and 3362cm−1) and NH bending (1560cm−1) vibrations [39] showed the presence of the amine functionality on the surface of silica (Fig. S4). 13C CP MAS NMR spectrum of 3 proved the formation of the imidazolium ring connected to the solid support resulting in the appearance of the signals at 122.1, 123.5 and 136.2ppm (Fig. S5). Also, the disappearance of NH stretching vibrations together with the bands at 1565, 1515, 1450 and 1410cm−1 (Fig. S4), attributed to the imidazole ring [40], are in accordance with the formation of modified silica 3. Further reaction with Br(CH2)3PPh3]Br (4) led to the dicationic moiety of SILP-2 with broad signals around 120–140ppm in the 13C CP MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. S6) corresponding to the carbon atoms of the aromatic ring. Similarly to SILP-1, the 29Si CP MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. S7) supported the formation of organosiloxane moieties and the signal at 17.7ppm in the 31P CP MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. S8) together with the strong band around 1440cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S4) proved the presence of the phosphonium salt [41]. (In the FT-IR spectra of all these modified silica phases the broad band around 3470–3450cm−1 corresponds to an overlap of the OH stretching of hydrogen-bonded water molecules and SiOH stretching of surface silanols hydrogen-bonded to water. Also, the absorption bands of deformation vibrations of adsorbed water molecules appear around 1650–1640cm−1 [42]. Palladium catalysts were prepared by immobilisation of Pd2(dba)3·CHCl3 on SILPs with phosphonium salts supported on silica by simple adsorption (Table 1 , CAT-0) or grafting (Table 1, CAT-1—CAT-3). Probably due to the low concentration of palladium on the surface, the presence of neither Pd2(dba)3 nor free dba could be detected by FT-IR (Figs. S9, S10). TEM measurements of CAT-2 (Fig. S12) proved the formation of palladium nanoparticles with an average diameter of 4.2±0.5nm. The same catalyst was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. XPS signals are merely originated from surface depth within 5nm, so does the calculated elemental composition given in Table 2 . The catalysts surface is rich with significant amount of Si in oxide form and organic carbon. Pd is in 0.4% atomic concentration on the surface and its line can be decomposed into two chemical states those are typical to Pd(0) and to Pd(II). Bands at 335.2eV and 340.5eV were assigned to the Pd(0) (3d5/2 and 3d3/2 respectively), and the ones at around 337.4eV and 342.6eV were typical to Pd(II) (3d5/2 and 3d3/2 respectively) (Fig. S13). Their atomic surface concentration is approximately the same. The ratios for the Pd, Si and C atoms are presented in Table 3 . Further elements as F, Br and P can be detected on the surface in a very low, ∼1% atomic concentration. The surface atomic concentration of N is ∼4% and it is typically in organic environment according to its line at 401.2eV. Overall these results are typical for Pd based molecular catalysts supported on silica [43–46]. 3.2 Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene (7a) with morpholine (8a) in the presence of the supported palladium catalysts Aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene (7a) with morpholine (8a) as the nucleophilic reaction partner was chosen as the model reaction (Scheme 3 ). First, the catalysts were tested in solvents of different polarity (DMF, THF and toluene) and at 30bar CO pressure or under atmospheric conditions. The double carbonylated product (9aa) was obtained with good selectivity at 30bar in DMF solvent and with Et3N base (Table 4 , entries 1, 6, 8, 12). In some cases side product 11, formed via decomposition of DMF [26], could be detected in the reaction mixture but its amount fell short of 3%. The use of THF also led to double carbonylation as the main reaction (entry 5). Lower conversion could be achieved under identical conditions in toluene (entries 4, 10). Moreover, a change in the ratio of the products in favour of amide 10aa could be observed. The use of DBU (1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene) that had been found to be an excellent base in double carbonylation reactions before [47] changed the selectivity and increased the amount of the α-ketoamide product 9aa (entries 5, 7, 11). The catalysts showed lower activity under atmospheric conditions (entries 2, 9). As it could be expected the main reaction was monocarbonylation but the formation of α-ketoamide 9aa could also be observed. The use of the catalysts prepared from the SILP phases with grafted cations (CAT-1 — CAT-3) resulted in the formation of α-ketoamide 9aa with good selectivity in DMF/Et3N and in toluene/DBU solvent/base systems. Among the three catalysts, CAT-1 showed lower activity in toluene (entry 7) and the ratio of amide product 10aa was a bit higher in case of CAT-3 (entry 12). On comparing the results with those obtained with catalysts supported on SILPs with imidazolium cations [25], a considerably higher activity of CAT-0, deposited on silica with physisorbed [MePh3P]Br, can be observed than the analogous one prepared with stabilising [1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium][BF4] (entries 1–4). The catalysts obtained with the two types of grafted ionic liquids gave identical results (entries 6,7). In heterogeneous reactions one of the main points is to ensure good recyclability of the catalysts. In the present case this could be achieved at 30bar CO pressure. Under atmospheric conditions the conversion dropped to 28% and 7% in the second run in the presence of CAT-0 and CAT-2, respectively. CAT-0 could be reused in both DMF (base: Et3N, Fig. 1 , a) and toluene (base: DBU, Fig. 1, c). At the same time the ratio of the side product (11) increased constantly and reached 30% in the 5th run in DMF. Selectivity for α-ketoamide 9aa was not particularly good in toluene with a maximum of 81%. In THF (Fig. 1, b) a marked drop of activity was observed after the second run. In DMF full conversion was obtained only in the first four cycles with CAT-1 (Fig. 2 , a). In toluene it retained its activity in 6 successive runs with conversions around 80% (Fig. 2, b). The total yield of the products was close to 70% even afterwards. The analogous catalyst with grafted imidazolium cations [25] showed poorer recyclability under the same conditions with a drop of conversion of iodobenzene to 55% in the 7th run and a quick loose of activity afterwards. The best recycling could be achieved with the catalyst prepared from the SILP-2 support with grafted dicationic moieties (CAT-2, Fig. 3 ). α-Ketoamide 9aa was formed with good selectivity in each case and amide 10aa was the only side product when the reaction was carried out in toluene. In the most successful experiments, the amount of palladium leached into the reaction mixtures was determined by ICP-AES (Table 5 ). In the reactions carried out with CAT-1 in DMF, leached palladium was below the detection limit (below 1% of the original load) in the first run but it increased to 4.1% in the second run and remained around this amount afterwards. In case of CAT-2 a considerable loss of palladium (16.1% of the original load) could be detected but leaching dropped to 3.6% in the second run and it decreased constantly to a 0.6% value in the 10th run. (The combined mixtures of runs 3–9 had a Pd-content of 4.7% of the original load that corresponds to an average below 0.7% for these cycles.) It seems that DMF dissolves some loosely-bound palladium in the first run. In spite of this, a more efficient recycling can be achieved than in case of CAT-1 together with a low palladium loss after the 2nd run. The lowest amount of leached palladium was detected in the reactions carried out in toluene with CAT-2. In this reaction less than 1% of the original palladium load was found in the reaction mixtures after each run. The differences in the palladium content of the catalysts (Table 1) show that the support with dicationic moieties is able to bind a higher amount of palladium. At the same time, the catalytic experiments proved that part of the metal is bonded loosely to the support and is removed easily by polar solvents such as DMF. That is why another catalyst (CAT-3, Table 1) was prepared with palladium deposited on the same support (SILP-2).This supported catalyst (CAT-3) was separated by filtration to remove non-immobilised palladium particles. As a result, a catalyst with lower palladium loading was obtained. (It should be mentioned that during the preparation of the other catalysts (CAT-0—CAT-2) the solvent used during immobilisation of palladium was removed by evaporation). Catalytic experiments showed that although palladium leaching was lower here in the first run (Table 5, entry 4) than in case of CAT-2 (entry 2), it did not change considerably upon reuse and a slow decrease in the conversion took place after the 4th run (Fig. S14). To obtain information about the homogeneous or heterogeneous nature of the catalytic reaction, hot filtration and mercury poising tests were carried out in the reactions of CAT-1 and CAT-2 (Table 6 ). The catalytic mixture was filtered after half an hour. One half of the mixture was heated further under CO pressure and the other was treated similarly but in the presence of mercury. In case of CAT-2 a total conversion could be achieved after the removal of the solid material using a fresh supply of catalyst (entry 1) in DMF. A similar procedure carried out with a spent catalyst showed that although some iodobenzene was consumed even in the absence of the heterogeneous catalyst (entry 3), the conversion was lower than in a typical second run experiment (compare Fig. 3, b). This is in accordance with the decrease in the amount of leached palladium after the first run. At the same time the reaction could be stopped in the presence of mercury (entries 2, 4). This shows that the catalytically active species that have leached to the reaction mixture are mainly nanoparticles not palladium complexes. No such difference of the performance of the spent catalyst was observed in case of CAT-1 (entries 7–10). No further reaction took place in toluene after the removal of the solid material (entries 5, 6, 11, 12) in accordance with the small loss of palladium observed. As a summary it can be stated that CAT-2 showed the best recyclability among the catalysts tested. An excellent selectivity towards double carbonylation product 9aa was observed in DMF at 30bar CO pressure. Palladium leaching could be reduced considerably in toluene. Although selectivity was somewhat lower in the latter case ratio of α-ketoamide 9aa still remained around 90%. Our previous studies showed that when palladium was supported on SILPs with imidazolium cations, efficient catalyst reuse could be achieved only in reactions with a long reaction time (8–12h) [25]. Catalyst CAT-2 with palladium immobilised on a silica surface modified with dicationic moieties showed good recyclability in three hour-long experiments so its use leads to a considerable decrease in reaction time. Also, modification of the surface of the support with phosphonium ions makes it possible to recycle the catalyst efficiently in double carbonylation carried out in apolar toluene. This results in a considerable decrease in palladium leaching. 3.3 Carbonylation of other nucleophiles/substrates Based on the previous results, aminocarbonylation of iodobenzene (7a) with other amines (8b-h, Scheme 4 ) as well as that of other iodoarenes (7b-e, Scheme 5 ) with morpholine (8a) was carried out with catalyst CAT-2 in DMF or in toluene (Table 7 ). Although the use of the latter solvent was proved to be the better choice in the reaction of iodobenzene (7a) with morpholine (8a), especially when palladium leaching was taken into account, in some cases DMF was the only suitable solvent. Some of the products precipitated from toluene that made recycling of the catalyst impossible. When such products were dissolved in methanol, the activity of the catalyst, recovered from the polar solvent by filtration, was found to decrease considerably. In the reactions of aliphatic amines (8b-d, Scheme 4), total conversion of iodobenzene could be achieved in 3 subsequent runs (Table 7, entries 1–8) and the corresponding α-ketoamides (9ab-9ad) were the main products. Both in DMF (entries 1,3,5,7) and in toluene (entries 2,4,6,8) an improvement in the selectivity of the reaction could be observed when the catalyst was reused. With diethylamine (8d) as the nucleophile, much better selectivity could be obtained by using the toluene/DBU system (entry 8). As in our previous studies [26], selective monocarbonylation took place when aniline derivatives (8e-h) were used as nucleophiles (entries 9–12). With the exception of the reaction of 4-butylaniline (8f) (entry 10) iodobenzene could totally be converted to the amide products even when the catalyst was recycled. Carbonylation of iodoarenes (7b-e, Scheme 5) could be carried out smoothly with CAT-2 (entries 13–17), but the selectivity of the reaction depended greatly on the nature of the substituent of the iodoarene. Slower reaction, together with a higher selectivity towards the double carbonylated product could be observed starting from 4-iodoanisole (7b) (entry 13). In case of the xylene derivative (7c), a stable performance of the catalyst, together with good selectivity was achieved in DMF (entry 14). The use of the toluene/DBU system led to improved selectivity but a loss of activity upon catalyst recycling (entry 15). The corresponding amide (10da) was formed as the main product starting from 4-nitro-iodobenzene (7d) (entry 16). Interestingly, carbonylation was accompanied in this case by a Buchwald-Hartwig coupling leading to 12 as the side product. Substitution of the bromo functionality was observed during carbonylation of 4-bromo-iodobenzene (7e) (entry 17). Beside the awaited α-ketoamide (9ea) and amide (10ea) products the presence of bis-α-ketoamide 13 could be detected by GC–MS in 14%, 19% and 14% yields in the three successive runs. The amount of bis-amide 14 was below 1% and no formation of a product with an amide — α-ketoamide substitution pattern could be observed. Unfortunately, attempts to convert bromobenzene, or even bromobenzene derivatives incorporating electron withdrawing substituents (e.g. 4-NO2-bromobenzene) to carbonylated products failed. 4 Conclusions It was demonstrated that silica materials with grafted phosphonium cations were suitable supports for palladium catalysts used in double carbonylation of iodoarenes with aliphatic amines. The corresponding α-ketoamides could be obtained with excellent selectivity in most cases. Carbonylation with aniline derivatives as nucleophilic reaction partners led to selective formation of amide products. A better stabilisation of the palladium catalyst could be achieved by introducing dicationic organic moieties incorporating both imidazolium and phosphonium ions on the surface of the support. In DMF solvent a stable catalyst is formed under carbonylation conditions after a conditioning first run. The catalyst could be reused at least nine times with total conversion of the starting material in the model reaction of iodobenzene (7a) with morpholine (8a). Recyclability was also proved during the carbonylation of other substrates. In contrast to catalysts immobilised on supports modified with imidazolium ions, the application of supported ionic liquid phases with phosphonium ions made it possible to carry out double carbonylation with good selectivity in apolar toluene which led to a considerable decrease in the amount of leached palladium. coredata.dc:description: The first heterogeneous carbonylation reaction carried out with palladium catalysts immobilised on phosphonium ion modified silica supports is reported. The supported ionic liquid phases were characterised by solid state NMR and FT-IR measurements. The presence of the phosphonium ions on the surface made it possible to carry out double carbonylation in apolar toluene efficiently that resulted in reduced metal leaching. The introduction of dicationic moieties on the solid support has been proved to lead to a further increase in catalyst stability. The catalysts were proved to produce α-ketoamide products with excellent selectivity in the carbonylation of iodoarenes with aliphatic amines while monocarbonylation was the only reaction observed with aniline derivatives. The catalysts could be recycled and used in at least 10 subsequent runs under optimised conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Double carbonylation of iodoarenes in the presence of reusable palladium catalysts immobilised on supported phosphonium ionic liquid phases
